Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the exciting events of recent years has been the mounting evidence that the very early universe underwent a period of accelerated expansion known as "primordial inflation". During primordial inflation there is a vast enhancement of quantum effects, which are ordinarily very small. Another significant feature of primordial inflation is that these quantum effects become fossilized so that they can be detected by current observers. The goals of this study are, among others, to work out how quantum effects arise from primordial inflation, to settle the long-standing controversy over whether or not the self-gravitation of particles produced during inflation can slow down the expansion of the universe and to investigate modified gravity theories which might describe the current universe.

Such a study is interesting because there is a vast reservoir of largely untapped data in the radiation from the very early structures which can be seen at great distances. This data offers sensitivity to energy scales and physical laws far beyond those that can be reached in accelerators such as the Large Hadron Collider. This project will promote teaching, training and learning. To this end, the PI will continue serving as a host in the University of Florida's Junior Science, Engineering and Humanities Symposium. These presentations typically involve simple explanations of, for example, why galactic rotation curves suggest dark matter. Then the PI discusses how students can prepare for a career in theoretical physics. The PI will also continue to deliver colloquia based on his 2009 review article, "How Far Are We from the Quantum Theory of Gravity?" in Reports on Progress in Physics. These colloquia are accessible to interested but non-specialist physicists, and to graduate students new to the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Primordial inflation is a phase of accelerated expansion which is conjectured to have occurred during the very early universe. The energy scale at that time was so high that quantum fluctuations in spacetime --- which are negligibly small today --- were large enough to be observable. There was also a mechanism whereby these fluctuations could ``fossilize'' --- just like dinosaur bones --- so that they could survive to be observed today. There are two kinds of fluctuations: those from the gravitational repsonse to quantum matter and those from gravity itself. The first has been resolved with ever-increasing precision since the 1992 COBE probe for which the 2006 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded. The second kind has not yet been resolved but hopes are high that a new generation of ultra-sensistive detectors will soon observe it. These fluctuiations are the first quantum gravitational data ever taken and they are catalyzing the transformation of quantum gravity from speculation into hard science.

This project concerns secondary effects which should occur when primordial fluctuations interact with one another or with ordinary particles such as electrons and photons. Although many researchers are studying these secondary effects they typically do so by employing approximations whose reliability cannot be accessed because there are so few exact results to serve as comparisons. Over the course of this project the PI and his collaborators have doubled the number of exact results. Some of these results have revealed significant mistakes with earlier approximation techniques. These results also show how primordial fluctuations modify electric and magnetic forces.

The conventional formalism of theoretical physics was developed to describe experiments at Earth-bound particl accelerators such as the Large Hadron Collider. This formalism does not apply to the cosmological setting in which the secondary effects manifest. For example, it is not clear precisely what theoretical quantities correspond to the observations which are being performed. The PI and his collaborators have made several proposals and have carried out studies to determine their suitability. The PI has also proposed techniques for overcoming the ambiguities associated with how one measures time and distance. And the PI has carried on an extensive dialog between representatives of different areas of fundamental theory to build a consensus regarding the computational techniques which must be employed to study secondary effects.

One of the fascinating properties of secondary effects is that some of them grow with time to the point that they can become very strong. It is conceivable that some of the strange phenomena we observe today --- dark energy and dark matter --- can be explained by secondary effects which grew to become strong during primordial inflation. The PI and his collaborators have studied this possibility from the perspective of fundamental theory and on the purely phenemological level of devising approximate models of an unconventional type which is motivated by the physics of secondary effects.

The principal broader impact of this project has been to provide STEM training to graduate students from under-represented groups. During the reporting period the PI graduated two women (Sohyun Park in 2012 and Katie Leonard in 2013) and one Hispanic (Pedro Mora in 2014). All have gone on to wonderful careers. Sohyun Park (who has 5 joint papers with the PI) is completing a 3-year postdoc at Penn State University, and follow that with a postdoc at KASI in her home nation of South Korea. Katie Leonard (who has 5 joint papers with the PI) first took a highly paid job at Applied Mathematics Inc in Gales Ferry, CT.
